definitions.definition: to produce tears from your eyes because you are unhappy or hurt
definitions.sensetop: cry for somebody/somethingcry about/over somethingcry with something+ speech

examples.text: It's all right. Don't cry.
I just couldn't stop crying.
The little boy fell over and started to cry.
The baby was crying for *(= because it wanted)* its mother.
There's nothing to cry about.
He felt like crying with rage.
She threw her arms around his neck crying tears of joy.
He started to cry real tears.
‘Waaa!’ she cried.
I found him **crying his eyes out** *(= crying very much)*.
That night she **cried herself to sleep**.
Anna was almost crying with frustration.
Finally he broke down and cried like a baby.
He put his head on his arms and cried bitterly.
I felt like I wanted to cry.
I felt like crying when I found out what had happened.
I wasn't going to waste time crying over him!
What are you crying about?
children who are left to cry alone
She ran to the window and cried for help.
‘You're safe!’ Tom cried in delight.
‘Never!’ he cried angrily.
‘What do you mean?’ she cried in agitation.
‘Who's there?’ she cried in a shrill voice.
He cried for help as the fire spread.

phrases: cry out in anguish, fear, pain

examples.text: Seagulls followed the boat, crying loudly.
A pair of eagles cried out to each other as they circled above the trees.

definitions.definition: to complain that somebody else has done something wrong or unfair
to waste time worrying about something that has happened that you cannot do anything about

examples.text: As the saying goes—**it's no use crying over spilt milk**.

definitions.definition: to call for help when you do not need it, with the result that when you do need it people do not believe you
used to show you are angry or surprised

examples.text: For crying out loud! Why did you have to do that?

definitions.definition: to laugh so long and hard that there are tears in your eyes
to be unable to decide how to react to a bad situation
used to describe a person who listens to your problems and gives you sympathy

examples.text: He was a fatherly shoulder to cry on when things went wrong.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘ask for earnestly or loudly’): from Old French crier (verb), cri (noun), from Latin quiritare ‘raise a public outcry’, literally ‘call on the Quirites (Roman citizens) for help’.
